title: Intelligence Specialist
name: Miriam Samuels

groups.name: The Job Seeker Networking Group - Find a Recruiter
Association of the United States Navy (AUSN)
Centre for study of Intelligence Operations

summary: I am professional and accomplished Intelligence Analyst with 18 years experience supporting military and national defense. I possess a TS/SCI/CI/Poly Clearance and I am now seeking career opportunities with defense, intelligence and security contractors to continue my career in intelligence community as a Signal Intelligence (SIGINT) Analyst. I am self-motivated individual and very proficient in multiple disciplines of Signals Analysis; SIGINT Geospatial Anlysis (SGA), Analysis and Reporting, Cyberspace Warfare, and proficient in multiple all source intelligence databases and tools including: PINWALE, HOMEBASE, ArcGIS, ARCVIEW, SEDB, FASCIA, DISHFIRE, MAINWAY, CPE, RENOIR, OCTAVE, ANCHORY/MAUI, CREST, AMHS, INTELINK, SPOTBEAM, BEAMER, SKYWRITER, CONTRACTIVE, GOOGLE EARTH, DRT, GCCS-M, TAC, SIGNAV and RFMP-Builder. I am a problem solver, critical thinker, motivated and dedicated team player who has proven results and communicates authoritatively, both orally and written. As a work-center Subject Matter Expert, I focused on activities in Middle Eastern and Africa regions for nine years and fuse intelligence from SIGINT and GEOINT collected resources to developed reliable intelligence reports or recommendation packages to support national mission assignments, effects planning, and non-kinetic fire mission. As a Senior Analyst, I helped managed all aspects of the mission requirements and built a client base by consistently providing excellent service. I am a great technical mentor and trainer and have authored five technical standard operation procedure (SOP) booklets to improve collection and training pipelines. I am willing to relocate to Maryland, Washington D.C., Northern Virginia, Augusta Georgia, San Diego CA, and overseas.

description: Some of the other factors that drive Safer City projects are: a strong city economy, level of safety and security threat, availability of internet protocol, susceptibility to natural disasters, improved private and public partnership, and so on. ‘Safer City’ concept is expected to witness significant traction over the next few years as external/internal threat factors are given more importance by governments across the world. The higher the internal/external threat of terrorist attacks, the more probability there is of a city implementing a safer city project. In terms of adoption, the North American market has already seen some rapid progress after the 9/11 attacks. New York City is one of the most “surveilled” cities in the world with video surveillance cameras located at almost every junction, intersection, building, and public area in the city. Other major cities such as Tokyo, Los Angeles, and so on, are on the forefront in adopting safer city projects and related technologies. As critical assets in a city’s infrastructure, security technologies and solutions in future cities will play an important role in promoting better well-being and will support city operators to better cope with security and safety challenges. In the next 5-10 years, Frost & Sullivan expects safer city projects to become integral part of a city’s development schemes proposed by the respective governmen
